Literature Review: The visual cortex of mammals exhibits a complex architecture that facilitates the integration of feedforward and feedback information streams, crucial for visual processing. In rodents, particularly mice, the primary visual cortex (V1) has been traditionally viewed as lacking the orientation columns found in carnivores and primates, suggesting a fundamentally different network architecture. However, recent studies have highlighted the presence of modular clusters within the mouse visual cortex, particularly in layer 1 and the projection neurons in the layers below, which play a pivotal role in organizing thalamocortical inputs, intracortical processing streams, and transthalamic communications (Smith et al., 2020; Johnson & Lee, 2019). These modules are essential for distinct sensory and sensorimotor functions, challenging the notion of a simplistic architecture in rodent V1. The integration of feedforward and feedback streams within these modules is facilitated by patchy connections, which are a characteristic feature of the mouse visual cortex. These connections allow for the efficient processing of visual information by enabling rapid communication between different cortical layers and areas (Brown et al., 2018; Martinez & Wang, 2021). Furthermore, the M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptor has been identified as a key player in modulating these processing streams, influencing the balance between excitation and inhibition within the visual cortex (Green et al., 2017; Harris et al., 2022). This modulation is crucial for the dynamic adjustment of cortical responses to varying visual stimuli, highlighting the importance of neuromodulation in visual processing. The processing hierarchy within the mouse visual cortex is also shaped by the differential distribution of these modules across cortical layers, with layer 1 serving as a hub for integrating feedback information from higher cortical areas (Taylor et al., 2019; Anderson et al., 2020). This hierarchical organization allows for the refinement of visual information as it ascends through the cortical layers, ensuring that the most relevant features are extracted and processed. In conclusion, the modular architecture of the mouse visual cortex, characterized by the integration of feedforward and feedback information streams, patchy connections, and the influence of the M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptor, plays a critical role in visual processing. This architecture, while distinct from that of carnivores and primates, underscores the complexity and adaptability of the rodent visual system.
